Detailed Description

Memory allocation functions and hooks.

These functions are used for all memory management performed by libnewtsclient. All other functions in the library dealing with memory allocation or deallocation call a function defined in this file.

The global function pointer variables in this file define the basic interface to memory management. If those variables are reassigned, the higher-level interface to memory management in this file, and by extension all other memory-related functions in libnewtsclient, will automatically use the new functions stored in those variables. If you need to handle memory allocation in a special way, for example to accommodate requirements for writing extensions for dynamic languages like Python, you can accomplish that by redefining these variables.

The higher-level interface provides error checking as well as numerous specialized variations of the basic memory allocation functions. If you're directly allocating memory (as opposed to using structure-specific allocation functions such as alloc_nfref), you should use this higher-level interface.

Function Documentation

void* newts_calloc ( size_t  number,
size_t  size 
)

Allocate and return sufficient memory for number items of size bytes each, all initialized to 0. size must be nonzero.

void newts_free ( void *  pointer  ) 

Free memory allocated by any of the allocation functions in this file.

void* newts_malloc ( size_t  size  ) 

Allocate and return size bytes of uninitializd memory.

void newts_malloc_die ( void   ) 

Abort execution in the case of failed memory allocation. This function is the default value of newts_failed_malloc_hook.

void* newts_memdup ( const void *  pointer,
size_t  size 
)

Allocate and return size bytes of memory, and fill that memory with the contents of the first size bytes of the memory starting at pointer.

void* newts_nmalloc ( size_t  number,
size_t  size 
)

Allocate and return sufficient uninitialized memory for number items of size bytes each. size must be nonzero.

void* newts_nrealloc ( void *  pointer,
size_t  number,
size_t  size 
)

If pointer is NULL, allocate and return sufficient uninitialized memory for number items of size bytes each. Otherwise, change the size of pointer to accommodate number items of size bytes each, and return the location of the newly resized block of memory. size must be nonzero.

void* newts_nrealloc2 ( void *  pointer,
size_t *  number,
size_t  size 
)

If pointer is NULL, allocate and return sufficient uninitialized memory to accommodate, at minimum, number items of size bytes each. If pointer is NULL and number is also NULL, allocate and return memory for some implementation-defined number of items of size bytes each.

If pointer is not NULL, change the size of pointer to accommodate at least number items of size bytes each, and return the location of the newly resized block of memory. If pointer is not NULL, size must not be NULL.

Repeated reallocations are guaranteed to "make progress", either by allocating an initial block with a nonzero size, or by reallocating a larger block.

Side effects:
number is set to the number of items of size size allocated; this may be greater than the number requested, but will never be fewer. On return, number will never contain a value of zero unless memory failed to be allocated.

void* newts_realloc ( void *  pointer,
size_t  size 
)

If pointer is NULL, allocate and return size bytes of uninitialized memory. Otherwise, change the size of pointer to size bytes, and return the location of the newly resized block of memory.

void* newts_realloc2 ( void *  pointer,
size_t *  size 
)

If pointer is NULL, allocate and return sufficient uninitialized memory to accommodate, at minimum, size bytes. If pointer is NULL and size is also NULL, allocate and return memory for some implementation-defined number of bytes.

If pointer is not NULL, change the size of pointer to accommodate at least size bytes, and return the location of the newly resized block of memory. If pointer is not NULL, size must not be NULL.

Repeated reallocations are guaranteed to "make progress", either by allocating an initial block with a nonzero size, or by reallocating a larger block.

Side effects:
size is set to the number of bytes allocated; this may be greater than the number requested, but will never be fewer. On return, size will never contain a value of zero unless memory failed to be allocated.

char* newts_strdup ( const char *  string  ) 

Allocate and return a copy of string.

void* newts_zalloc ( size_t  size  ) 

Allocate and return size bytes of memory, initialized to 0.

Variable Documentation

void(* newts_failed_malloc_hook)(void)

A function that should be called if newts_malloc_function or newts_realloc_function fails to successfully allocate or reallocate memory. Defaults to newts_malloc_die.

This function is permitted to abort execution, but is not required to, if the client application prefers to raise an exception, attempt to recover memory, or otherwise handle the allocation error gracefully.

void(* newts_free_function)(void *pointer)

The function that should be used to deallocate pointers allocated using either newts_malloc_function or newts_realloc_function. Defaults to free(3).

This function is called by newts_free.

void*(* newts_malloc_function)(size_t size)

The function that should be used to allocate new blocks of memory. Defaults to malloc(3).

This function is called by newts_calloc, newts_malloc, newts_memdup, newts_nmalloc, newts_strdup, and newts_zalloc.

See also:
newts_free_function

void*(* newts_realloc_function)(void *pointer, size_t size)

The function that should be used to re-allocate blocks of memory previously allocated by newts_malloc_function. Defaults to realloc(3).

This function is called by newts_nrealloc, newts_nrealloc2, newts_realloc, and newts_realloc2.

See also:
newts_free_function

void(* newts_successful_malloc_hook)(void *pointer)

A function that should be called if newts_malloc_function or newts_realloc_function successfully allocates or reallocates memory. No default value.

Parameters:
pointer The address of the newly allocated or reallocated memory.
